Module JBubbleBobble
Package game.model.entities

Class MovingEntity

java.lang.Object
game.model.entities.Entity
game.model.entities.MovingEntity
Direct Known Subclasses:
Bolt, Bubble, Enemy, FireBall, Laser, Player, Water
public abstract class MovingEntity extends Entity
The MovingEntity class represents an entity in the game that can move, jump, and interact with the environment. It extends the Entity class and adds additional properties and methods for movement, collision handling, gravity effects, and more.

  • Constructor Details

    • MovingEntity

      public MovingEntity(float x, float y, char code)
      Constructs a MovingEntity with specified position and unique code. Default values are assigned for gravity, jump speed, fall speed after collision, and maximum falling speed.
      Parameters:
      x - The x-coordinate of the entity.
      y - The y-coordinate of the entity.
      code - The unique code representing the entity.

    • MovingEntity

      public MovingEntity(float x, float y, float width, float height, char code)
      Constructs a MovingEntity with specified position, dimensions, and unique code. Default values are assigned for gravity, jump speed, fall speed after collision, and maximum falling speed.
      Parameters:
      x - The x-coordinate of the entity.
      y - The y-coordinate of the entity.
      width - The width of the entity.
      height - The height of the entity.
      code - The unique code representing the entity.

  • Method Details

    • getxSpeed

      public float getxSpeed()
      Gets the current speed of the entity along the x-axis.
      Returns:
      The x-axis speed of the entity.

    • getAirSpeed

      public float getAirSpeed()
      Gets the current speed of the entity while it is in the air.
      Returns:
      The air speed of the entity.

    • getDirection

      public MovingEntity.Direction getDirection()
      Gets the current movement direction of the entity.
      Returns:
      The direction of the entity.

    • setxSpeed

      public void setxSpeed(float xSpeed)
      Sets the speed of the entity along the x-axis.
      Parameters:
      xSpeed - The new x-axis speed of the entity.

    • setAirSpeed

      public void setAirSpeed(float airSpeed)
      Sets the speed of the entity while it is in the air.
      Parameters:
      airSpeed - The new air speed of the entity.

    • setJumpSpeed

      public void setJumpSpeed(float jumpSpeed)
      Sets the speed at which the entity jumps.
      Parameters:
      jumpSpeed - The new jump speed of the entity.

    • setDirection

      public void setDirection(MovingEntity.Direction direction)
      Sets the movement direction of the entity.
      Parameters:
      direction - The new movement direction of the entity.

    • updateXPos

      public void updateXPos()
      Updates the entity's position along the x-axis based on its speed and the ability to move. Handles collisions with obstacles or walls, adjusting the position to prevent moving through objects.

    • updateYPos

      protected void updateYPos()
      Updates the entity's position along the y-axis based on air speed, gravity, and collisions. Handles situations where the entity is in the air, hits the roof, or goes out of bounds on the screen.

    • resetInAir

      public void resetInAir()
      Resets the in-air state and air speed of the entity. This is typically called after the entity lands on the ground.

    • stop

      public void stop()
      Stops the entity's movement by setting its direction to STATIC and setting its xSpeed to 0. This effectively halts the entity's horizontal motion.

    • move

      public void move(float speed)
      Moves the entity based on the current direction and a specified speed.
      Parameters:
      speed - The speed at which to move the entity.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the direction is unexpected.

    • updateEntity

      public void updateEntity()
      Updates the entity's state, including movement, gravity, and any other relevant changes. This method should be called every game tick to ensure the entity behaves as expected.
